title: Pallbearer who snubbed Mitch McConnell at Cummings's memorial blames him for brother's death
text:
The pallbearer who snubbed Senator Mitch McConnell at a memorial service for Elijah Cummings last Thursday has said he couldn't shake hands with someone who refused to help his Marine veteran brother before he died of cancer.

Bobby Rankin explained what was going on in his mind when he skipped the Republican and went straight to greet Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi at the Capitol, a day before the one-year anniversary of the loss.

The 64-year-old's brother, Jerry, lost his 10-year battle with myeloma cancer October 2016 and the deadly disease is believed to be connected to being exposed to contaminated water while serving in Camp Lejeune in North Carolina.

The Department of Veteran Affairs said those exposed to solvents, benzene and other chemicals in the drinking water were entitled to free healthcare and other benefits but Jerry didn't receive them, Rankin said.

'When I saw Mitch McConnell, all I saw was my brother's face,' Rankin told the Washington Post about Jerry who died a year ago on Friday. 'Elijah Cummings reached across party lines trying to help my brother get his military benefits, and Mitch McConnell was one of the persons he reached out to.'

Bobby Rankin refused to shake Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's hand at a memorial service for the late Elijah Cummings in the Capitol on Thursday (pictured) because he 'refused to help' his Marine brother Jerry before he died of cancer in October 2016

His brother Jerry (right), died in October 2016 from cancer after being exposed to contaminated water while serving in the Marines at Camp Lejeune in North Carolina. Bobby Rankin is pictured left

In the video, Rankin hugs House Majority Whip Jim Clyburn (D-SC) before shaking the hands of House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-MD), House Minority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY).

But Rankin bypasses McConnell (R-KY), who was standing next to Schumer, as he goes to hug Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi (D-CA).

Rankin believes McConnell is partially to blame for Jerry's death after he never got the disability compensation he was entitled to.

'I could not put my hands in the man's hand who refused to help somebody who served his country,' Rankin explained. He added: 'I couldn't do it, because I was thinking about my brother.'

Senate Majority Leader McConnell appeared stunned by the refusal to shake hands at the late congressman's memorial service.

Footage of the moment has been viewed 2.1 million times since it was uploaded to Twitter on Thursday.

McConnell's reps have not responded to the Washington Post's request for comment.

It's unclear why Charlotte, North Carolina man Jerry didn't get the benefits.

Rankin was also listed as a pallbearer for Cummings's funeral on Friday.

He told the Post: 'When I carry him to his grave, if I could say something to him, I would say something I said to him many, many times before. What a mighty, mighty man he is.'

Jerry is pictured with his son Quinton Rankin in a post paying tribute to the man who battled myeloma for at least 16 years

Rankin was seen in the video hugging House Majority Whip Jim Clyburn (left) and shaking the hands of House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (right), House Minority Whip Kevin McCarthy and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY)

The clip then shows Rankin bypassing McConnell to chat with Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi. Pictured: Rankin shakes hands with Schumer

Rankin met Cummings at a gas station years back and they formed a friendship after they got chatting.

According to the Christian Recorder, Rankin is an AMEC Security Specialist for the AME Church and first gave his brother bone marrow 22 years ago.

Despite the snub on Thursday, McConnell eulogized Cummings during the memorial service and described as a man who 'did not just represent Baltimore, he embodied it.'

'He celebrated its victories, sought to advocate for its needs, and worked to heal its wounds,' McConnell said.

'He knew there was only one reason why a son of sharecroppers, a child who had literally had to bear the injuries of bigotry, and segregation, could graduate from law school, and eventually chair, a powerful committee in Congress.

Rankin said: 'Elijah Cummings reached across party lines trying to help my brother get his military benefits, and Mitch McConnell was one of the persons he reached out to'

'Only one reason, because principle leaders had fought to give kids like him a chance.'

Cummings, who was a leading force in the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump, was eulogized on Friday by former presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton in his hometown of Baltimore.

Hillary Clinton, who lost to Trump in the 2016 presidential election, also honored Cummings at a 10am funeral service at the city's New Psalmist Baptist Church.

A son of sharecroppers, Cummings served for 22 years in the US House of Representatives before his death on October 17.

He was an ardent civil rights voice who decades ago endured violence from white mobs as he and other African-Americans sought to integrate a public swimming pool.

The 13-term congressman was credited with helping calm tensions in Baltimore in 2015 when violence erupted following the death of an African-American man, Freddie Gray, in police custody.

Cummings was also a high-profile antagonist of Trump, who launched his June 2015 campaign for president promising to crack down on illegal immigration, saying Mexico was sending rapists into the United States.

Two years later as president, Trump reacted to a weekend of deadly violence during a 'Unite the Right' rally in Virginia saying there were 'very fine people' on both sides of the demonstrations.

Cummings served for 22 years in the US House of Representatives before his death on October 17. Pictured: The flag-draped casket of Cummings is escorted up the East Front Steps of the US Capital on Thursday

Before his death, Cummings death led a series of investigations into Trump's administration and business dealings. Pictured, from left: Pelosi, McConnell, Schumer, McCarthy, Hoyer James Clyburn and Senator Ben Cardin, look on as Cummings's casket of arrives for a ceremony in Statuary Hall at the US Capitol on Thursday

Cummings was an ardent civil rights voice who endured violence from white mobs as he a sought to integrate a public swimming pool. Pictured: McConnell and Schumer pay respects at a memorial service for Cummings at the US Capitol Hill on Thursday

McConnell was one of several who eulogized Cummings during the memorial service. The Senator described Cummings as a man who 'did not just represent Baltimore, he embodied it'

The funeral was held in Cummings's congressional district, which Trump vilified earlier this year as 'disgusting, rat and rodent infested.'

Cummings responded by saying Trump should visit his majority-black congressional district. 'I'll ride with him for hours...I want him to see all of the wonderful things that are happening.'

As chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, Cummings before his death led a series of investigations into Trump's administration and business dealings.

He had been a central figure in Democrats' ongoing impeachment inquiry into the president's dealings with Ukraine.
description: Bobby Rankin, one of the pallbearers, was seen shaking lawmakers' hands at a service for Elijah Cummings Thursday but not Mitch McConnell who he claims snubbed his Marine late brother Jerry.
